page.title: 08Transport
page.content: Boats brought supplies to Inchkeith from the early days of the lighthouse, visiting it four times a month and twice on Sundays, so that the lightkeepers could go to church. The boat men were usually fishermen or otherwise unoccupied lightkeepers. Communications between the island and shore have greatly improved over the years. Boats and casual visitors are more frequent, there is a helicopter landing pad in the lighthouse courtyard and there is also a direct telephone line to the island. On the island the lightkeepers use an old tractor as a means of transport between the lighthouse and harbour. The improvement of communications between the island and mainland has also had disadvantages - vandals have actually come out in boats and smashed windows, spray-painted walls etc.
